issue.title: Make asset watcher work when path contains "../"

labels.name: A-Assets
labels.description: Load files from disk to use for things like images, models, and sounds

labels.name: S-Ready-For-Final-Review

labels.name: X-Contentious
labels.description: There are nontrivial implications that should be thought through

labels.name: D-Straightforward
labels.description: Simple bug fixes and API improvements, docs, test and examples

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
# Objective

Fixes #18022

## Solution

Canonicalize asset paths

## Testing

I ran the examples `sprite`, `desk_toy` and `game_menu` with the feature `file_watcher` enabled. All correctly updated an asset when the source file was altered.

body: I would prefer an "secure-by-default" approach to filesystem access. Docs alone are not adequate, and the default stance should be secure. Users who need to break these rules locally should encounter a nice error that says "you can't do this for security reasons! Go change this setting to enable it!"

That makes sense.

By my searching of the code base, there are only a few places that the file system is accessed outside of the `bevy_asset` crate:
- `BevyManifest` (bevy_macro_utils/src/bevy_manifest.rs) which is only used by macro crates.
- The `headless_render` example.
- The `build-templated-pages` tool.

My search was done by looking for the text "std::fs", "std::path", and "async_fs", finding all uses of structs and functions those crates expose, then tracing their usage outwards until I hit something public facing.

Unless there's something I missed, only the `AssetPlugin` needs to know how to handle out-of-bounds directories, so a bool in the plugin struct should be sufficient to control that.

> Unless there's something I missed, only the AssetPlugin needs to know how to handle out-of-bounds directories, so a bool in the plugin struct should be sufficient to control that.

A bool in the plugin struct is a great place to start :) Longer term, I think we may want to also expose more granular control, to allow for risky operations inside of a generally robust application. That can wait until our assets API is more fully fleshed out though.
How about an enum with `Allow`, `Warn`, `Panic` options?

I don't think warn really meets the needs of any users. I'd start with a bool, and then move towards a clippy-flavored `Allow/Deny/Forbid` enum, where the difference between deny and forbid is allowing overrides.
How would we create a way to override Deny without re exposing the security hole?

Panic when calling the normal methods, and only allow the risky usage during specialized method calls. When Forbid is enabled, we would panic there too.

On reflection it might make sense to just have safe and risky API calls, but I don't know if we can sensibly get there right away.

Here is a draft: https://github.com/Threadzless/bevy/tree/asset-safety

This implements a Allow/Deny/Forbid enum, where Deny puts an warning in the terminal, and Forbid panics. Forbid is the default. I included a test for the Forbid case.

There is currently no way to override Forbid. If there was another method, like `AssetServer::load_override`, mods could just use that method.

I don't see a path to allowing overrides without re exposing the vulnerability.

Without overrides in place we should just use a bool :)

> If there was another method, like AssetServer::load_override, mods could just use that method.

Most mods won't be writing / shipping Rust code, and if they were, these protections won't help (they can call std::fs). Instead, I would expect these functionalities to be exposed to mods via an API that can be called by e.g. Lua code. Then, you call the checked version based on what you see in that API, and use the unchecked version for whatever high-risk thing that the game itself needs.

Oh right. now i feel silly.

I added AssetServer::load_override and similar methods to the draft
